Surprisingly enough, logic and reason were a major topic of those in the 17th century. It shaped them. They had a need for knowledge, to know the “why's,” and "the how's."     In this paper, I will be discussing the story of Sor Juana Ines De La Cruz, as well as how logic and reason were used not just in her lifetime, but also during the 17th century. As people, we are inherently emotional. We tend to survive off of emotion rather than logic. We tend to do what feels right, even when we know the logical answer is typically the opposite. Surprisingly enough, logic and reason were a major topic of those in the 17th century. It shaped them. They had a need for knowledge, to know the “why's,” and "the how's." The actual definition for reason is," A statement or fact that explains why something is the way it is, why someone does, thinks, or says something, or why someone behaves a certain way." Today, I will be diving into the story or Sor Juana Inez De La Cruz, and her thought process. 

 

    The story is about a controversial nun, who had a desire to learn. She was known far and wide for her sharp intellect and unwavering commitment to logic and reason. Even as a child, the desire was strong. She always had a longing to know more. To understand the things around her. Although she was very disciplined in her actions, she did not just act on reason and logic alone. As she entered adulthood, her reputation for reasoning and her commitment to bettering herself grew. Reading her story gives such an amazing insight on just how strong willed she was. 

 

    It was clear from a young age that she was gifted, and she was encouraged to learn more even though societal norms during that time frowned upon women being knowledgeable. As she grew older, her thirst was so insatiable that she went to great lengths in order to learn as much as possible. In the story, it talks about how she would set her sights on learning a certain topic, by the time her hair had grown past a desired length, if she was not versed enough in said topic, she would cut her hair off and start over again. This goes to show how committed she was to herself. 

 

    SH

    In this paper, I will be discussing the story of Sor Juana Ines De La Cruz, as well as how logic and reason were used not just in her lifetime, but also during the 17th century. She was a woman who was beyond her time, and challenged societal norms as well as constraints placed upon her gender. As people, we are inherently emotional. We tend to survive off of emotion rather than logic. We tend to do what feels right, even when we know the logical answer is typically the opposite. Surprisingly enough, logic and reason were a major topic of those in the 17th century. It shaped them. They had a need for knowledge, to know the “why's,” and "the how's." The actual definition for reason is," A statement or fact that explains why something is the way it is, why someone does, thinks, or says something, or why someone behaves a certain way." Today, I will be diving into the story or Sor Juana Inez De La Cruz, and her thought process. 

 

    The story is about a controversial nun, who had a desire to learn. She was known far and wide for her sharp intellect and unwavering commitment to logic and reason. Even as a child, the desire was strong. She always had a longing to know more. To understand the things around her. Although she was very disciplined in her actions, she did not just act on reason and logic alone. As she entered adulthood, her reputation for reasoning and her commitment to bettering herself grew. Reading her story gives such an amazing insight on just how strong willed she was. 

 

    It was clear from a young age that she was gifted, and she was encouraged to learn more even though societal norms during that time frowned upon women being knowledgeable. As she grew older, her thirst was so insatiable that she went to great lengths in order to learn as much as possible. In the story, it talks about how she would set her sights on learning a certain topic, by the time her hair had grown past a desired length, if she was not versed enough in said topic, she would cut her hair off and start over again. This goes to show how committed she was to herself. 

 

    While I myself am not a feminist, reading her writings and understanding how she did everything she did out of spite gives me great pleasure. She was a woman who challenged societal norms, as well as the constraints placed upon her gender. She pushed herself and showed women from that time that it too was possible for them to learn, and that men were not the higher power, whether they themselves believed that or not. Analyzing Logic and How it Shaped Those of the 17th Century.

 

    In this paper, I will be discussing the story of Sor Juana Ines De La Cruz, as well as how logic and reason were used not just in her lifetime, but also during the 17th century. She was a woman who was beyond her time, and challenged societal norms as well as constraints placed upon her gender. As people, we are inherently emotional. We tend to survive off of emotion rather than logic. We tend to do what feels right, even when we know the logical answer is typically the opposite. Surprisingly enough, logic and reason were a major topic of those in the 17th century. It shaped them. They had a need for knowledge, to know the “why's,” and "the how's." The actual definition for reason is," A statement or fact that explains why something is the way it is, why someone does, thinks, or says something, or why someone behaves a certain way." Today, I will be diving into the story or Sor Juana Inez De La Cruz, and her thought process. 

 

    The story is about a controversial nun, who had a desire to learn. She was known far and wide for her sharp intellect and unwavering commitment to logic and reason. Even as a child, the desire was strong. She always had a longing to know more. To understand the things around her. Although she was very disciplined in her actions, she did not just act on reason and logic alone. As she entered adulthood, her reputation for reasoning and her commitment to bettering herself grew. Reading her story gives such an amazing insight on just how strong willed she was. 

 

    It was clear from a young age that she was gifted, and she was encouraged to learn more even though societal norms during that time frowned upon women being knowledgeable. As she grew older, her thirst was so insatiable that she went to great lengths in order to learn as much as possible. In the story, it talks about how she would set her sights on learning a certain topic, by the time her hair had grown past a desired length, if she was not versed enough in said topic, she would cut her hair off and start over again. This goes to show how committed she was to herself. 

 

    While I myself am not a feminist, reading her writings and understanding how she did everything she did out of spite gives me great pleasure. She was a woman who challenged societal norms, as well as the constraints placed upon her gender. She pushed herself and showed women from that time that it too was possible for them to learn, and that men were not the higher power, whether they themselves believed that or not. This goes to show that while she did operate a considerable amount off of reason, she also had feelings. A quote that I came to appreciate from her gives a better insight on how her mind works and why she used logic so religiously. The quote goes," How, without logic, was I supposed to know the general and particular methods used in the writing in the Holy Scripture? How, without rhetoric, would I understand its figures, tropes, and locutions? How, without physics, comprehend the many inherent questions concerning the nature of the animals used for sacrifices, in which so many stated subjects, as well as many others that are undeclared, are symbolized."

She pushed herself and showed women from that time that it too was possible for them to learn, and that men were not the higher power, whether they themselves believed that or not. This goes to show that while she did operate a considerable amount off of reason, she also had feelings. A quote that I came to appreciate from her gives a better insight on how her mind works and why she used logic so religiously. The quote goes," How, without logic, was I supposed to know the general and particular methods used in the writing in the Holy Scripture? How, without rhetoric, would I understand its figures, tropes, and locutions? How, without physics, comprehend the many inherent questions concerning the nature of the animals used for sacrifices, in which so many stated subjects, as well as many others that are undeclared, are symbolized." 

 

    This woman's legacy burned brightly. She was such a knowledgeable person that I am not ashamed to say I struggled to easily understand what she was saying sometimes. Her thought process was so complex for a woman of her time. This is a story that you have to sit down and study every word for to understand just how great it is. I thoroughly enjoyed looking at this text. Through her words she inspired so many people in her time. She ignited fires in women showing them that there is no separation of us between men. She inspired them to pursue what they wanted. Reading about her life should remind those of us now that, no matter the challenges we face, we can rise above them and carve whatever path we want to take in life. She did not care about the harsh words thrown at her, the doubts that others had. She believed in herself and made it happen. I think people today could read her story and take something from it.
